headline: Starwatch: The March night sky
text: The two brightest planets, Venus and Jupiter, are converging for a spectacular conjunction in our W evening sky, as the two smallest ones, Mercury and Mars, are also at their best for the year. Indeed, Mars comes to opposition on the 3rd and is at its closest (101 million km) on the 5th. All of these planets rival or surpass Sirius the Dog Star which toddles across the S behind Orion as the latter strides into our lower W sky by our map times. Between the 1st and the 11th, Mercury stands 10 high in the W 30 minutes after sunset, sets more than one hour later and dims sharply from mag 0.8 to 1.1. Dazzling Venus brightens from mag 4.2 to 4.4 and is higher in our evening sky than it has been since 2004. Climbing onto our map as it moves from Pisces to Taurus, it passes N of Jupiter (fainter at mag 2.2 to 2.0) on the 15th and is nearing the Pleiades by the 31st. It lies within 5 of Jupiter, and inside a binocular field-of-view, from the 9th to the 17th. Telescopically, the 63% sunlit 19 arcsec disc of Venus on the 1st evolves to a 49% and 25 arcsec crescent by the 31st. Jupiter is 35 arcsec wide when they meet. Look for the earthlit crescent Moon just to the right of Jupiter on the 25th and below-left of Venus a day later. Mars, obvious and reddish low in the E at nightfall, climbs to cross the meridian less than two hours after our map times. Tracking westwards (retrograding) in Leo, it moves to within 6 of Regulus by the 31st and is near the almost-full Moon on the night of the 7th. The planet is mag 1.2 and 13.9 arcsec wide through a telescope at opposition. Saturn, mag 0.4 and retrograding 7 to the left of Spica in Virgo, stands low in the ESE at our map times. Its disc is 19 arcsec wide at midmonth, with the rings inclined towards us by 15.
